Research Services   Training & Education   Community Engagement                                  Home            Print  Email               - A + A                                                                                                                                                                         NYU-HHC Clinical and Translational Science Institute                                          Translating Research into Better Health   The New York University (NYU) – Health and Hospitals Corporation (HHC) Clinical and Translational Science Institute (CTSI) was established in 2009 through a Clinical and Translational Science Award (CTSA) from the National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences (NCATS). The NYU-HHC CTSI supports clinical and translational research that transforms health care and improves community health. We achieve this mission through an innovative public-private partnership of institutions with unique and complementary strengths: a private research university with a history of public service and substantial biomedical, behavioral, and population health expertise (NYU), the largest municipal healthcare system in the United States (HHC), a state psychiatric institute (Nathan Kline Institute), and numerous community organizations that represent the rich diversity of NYC. As a central hub, the CTSI catalyzes collaborative research and facilitates access to essential services, resources, and expertise necessary to engage in the full spectrum of clinical and translational research across our partners and the nationwide CTSA network.                                                              Research Services                     Research Guidance   Funding Support & Opportunities   Research Resources   Support for Collaboration   HHC Researcher Resources        More               Training & Education                     Degree Programs   Certificate Programs   Career Development Programs   Mentoring Programs        More               CTSI News & Events                     Newsletters   Calendar        More                                                                                  Quick Links       CTSI Newsletter   Cite the CTSI   Contact Us                Announcements       Funding Opportunity Announcement: Collaborative Innovation Awards                                                                                                                  NYU Langone Medical Center       Student Login       Library                 Policies & Disclaimers

Amongst other forms of assistance, help is available to:    Explain the purpose, operations and various components of the CTSI   Provide information on CTSI resources/services and who/how to contact the cores that provide them   Determine which CTSI funding mechanism is appropriate for your project and how to submit an application   Navigate the NYU regulatory system, including the NYU Institutional Review Board (IRB) and the Bellevue Research Committee   Refer you to experts for protocol and budget development   Provide information about the national ResearchMatch volunteer research registry, which brings together researchers and willing volunteers who wish to get involved with research studies.   To request help from the Research Concierge, please first fill out a Service Request Form . Then, you may contact the Research Concierge . To achieve this goal, a collaborative network of local, regional, and national research centers was developed to improve patient management through quality clinical research.   The Clinical and Translational Research offices are strategically located in the 70,000 square-foot Clinical and Translational Science Institute (CTSI). Comprised of three floors plus ground-floor space, the CTSI is populated by a number of dry research programs in population sciences, community health, epidemiology and bioinformatics. The facility is designed to accommodate growth in clinical research activity and to address the objective of the Medical Center's Campus Transformation of moving non-clinical functions off campus. The Clinical and Translational Research space is located in the heart of the CTSI and includes offices and flexible work spaces with direct access to conference centers with multi-media, class rooms, dedicated servers and databases, and secured medical research record storage space.   Research fellowship training opportunities in the Clinical and Translation Research Program, as well as Masters Degrees in Public Administration in Health Policy and Management, Global Health Leadership, and Science in Clinical Investigation are available for qualified individuals.   Active areas under clinical investigation in the Department of Plastic Surgery include: wound healing, cleft surgery, presurgical infant orthopedics, breast reconstruction, hand surgery, and craniosynostosis.
